title: 2014 Super League Grand Final
text:
The 2014 Super League Grand Final was the 17th official Grand Final and conclusive and deciding match of <a href="Super%20League%20XIX">Super League XIX</a>. It was held on Saturday 11 October 2014, at <a href="Old%20Trafford%20%28football%20ground%29">Old Trafford</a>, Manchester with a 6pm kick-off time. The game was played between the top two teams from the regular season, <a href="2014%20St%20Helens%20RLFC%20season">St Helens RLFC</a> and <a href="Wigan%20Warriors">Wigan Warriors</a>.
Background.
The 2014 <a href="Super%20League">Super League</a> season (known as the First Utility <a href="Super%20League%20XIX">Super League XIX</a> due to sponsorship by <a href="First%20Utility">First Utility</a>) was the 19th season of <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> football since the <a href="Super%20League">Super League</a> format was introduced in 1996. Fourteen teams competed for the <a href="League%20Leaders%27%20Shield">League Leaders' Shield</a> over 27 rounds (including the <a href="Magic%20Weekend">Magic Weekend</a> in Manchester), after which the highest finishing teams will enter the play-offs to compete for a place in the Grand Final and a chance to win the championship and the Super League Trophy.
Match details.
 Following a fiery opening that started with the kind of big tackles that this derby game has become known for, the game suffered a dramatic twist in only the second minute of the game when Wigan Prop, <a href="Ben%20Flower">Ben Flower</a>, became the first and only player to be sent off in a grand final by referee <a href="Phil%20Bentham">Phil Bentham</a> after he punched <a href="Lance%20Hohaia">Lance Hohaia</a> in the face, thus knocking him out, then as he lay defenceless on the floor, he punched him in the face again. 
This forced <a href="Wigan%20Warriors">Wigan</a> to play 78 minutes with 12-men, causing a switch in the Wigan approach to one of smash-and-grab. A valiant first-half performance by Wigan's 12-men meant they entered the break with a 6–2 lead.
Despite further strong defensive displays by the Wigan outfit in the ensuing second-half, <a href="Iosia%20Soliola">Iosia Soliola</a> forced himself over the Wigan try-line in his final appearance in the Red-Vee to put <a href="St%20Helens%20R.F.C.">St. Helens</a> ahead, and in control of the game. An admirable, yet desperate display by Wigan, to get themselves back into contention was halted, when <a href="Tommy%20Makinson">Tommy Makinson</a> crashed over for Saints, 12 minutes from time to make the score 14–6, after a precise kick over-the-top of the Wigan defence from Saints stalwart, <a href="Paul%20Wellens">Paul Wellens</a>. Despite a late Wigan flurry, <a href="Tommy%20Makinson">Makinson's</a> try proved to be the one that sealed the game and the championship for <a href="St%20Helens%20R.F.C.">St. Helens</a>, meaning that the Saints claimed their first championship title since 2006, and their sixth overall in the Super League era (St Helens are now equal with <a href="Leeds%20Rhinos">Leeds Rhinos</a> for titles since 1996, both have 6 titles).
World Club Series.
By winning this match the Saints had qualified for the <a href="World%20Club%20Challenge">World Club Series</a> Final, to be played early in the 2015 season against the winners of the <a href="2014%20NRL%20Grand%20final">2014 NRL Grand final</a>, the <a href="South%20Sydney%20Rabbitohs">South Sydney Rabbitohs</a>.
